function_call.name: get_risks
function_call.arguments: {"risks":[{"Description":"Use of county-level data for analyzing COVID-19 spread and mortality may oversimplify the geographic heterogeneity of the disease.","Impact":"Inaccurate understanding of spatial trends in COVID-19 spread and mortality, leading to ineffective public health interventions.","Mitigation":"Incorporate finer geographic data to capture localized variations in disease spread and mortality.","Technologies":"Geospatial analysis, GIS mapping tools.","People":"Public health authorities, epidemiologists, researchers.","Owner":"Research institutions, public health organizations."},{"Description":"Failure to consider the complete pathway between built and natural environment, chronic disease, and COVID-19 mortality rates may lead to incomplete understanding of disease transmission dynamics.","Impact":"Incomplete identification of environmental factors influencing COVID-19 transmission, hindering effective mitigation strategies.","Mitigation":"Integrate built and natural environment data with chronic disease prevalence to establish comprehensive risk factors for COVID-19 transmission.","Technologies":"Data integration platforms, environmental sensors.","People":"Environmental health specialists, urban planners, epidemiologists.","Owner":"Environmental research institutions, public health agencies."},{"Description":"Reliance on data from a single source for built and natural environment measures may introduce bias or inaccuracies in the analysis.","Impact":"Misinterpretation of environmental influences on COVID-19 spread and mortality, leading to misguided interventions and policies.","Mitigation":"Validate data from multiple sources to ensure accuracy and reliability of environmental variables.","Technologies":"Data validation tools, satellite imagery, remote sensing technologies.","People":"Data analysts, environmental scientists, public health researchers.","Owner":"Research institutions, environmental monitoring agencies."}]}
